translated: The Buddha Speaks the SÅ«tra of the Nine-Colored Deer
Translated by the UpÄsaka Zhi Qian of the Yuezhi in the Wu Region
The Buddha said: In the past, the Bodhisattva was a nine-colored deer; its fur had nine colors,
and its antlers were white as snow. It always stayed by the Ganges River, eating water and grass, and was always acquainted with a crow.

At that time, there was a drowning person in the water who was carried downstream, sometimes emerging and sometimes submerging, and managed to grab onto a tree branch. He looked up and called out to the heavens:
Mountain spirits, tree spirits, heavenly dragon spirits, why do you not have pity on me?
The deer heard the person's cries and immediately ran to the water's edge, and said to the drowning person:
You should not be afraid!
You can ride on my back and hold onto my antlers. I will carry you out onto the shore.

The deer was extremely exhausted, and the drowning person got off the ground, circled the deer three times, and kowtowed to the deer, begging to become the deer's servant and provide service and collect water and grass.
The deer said:
'I do not need you. Go away now. If you wish to repay my kindness, do not tell others that I am here. People covet my skin and horns and will surely come to kill me.'
Then the drowning man accepted the instruction and left.
At that time, the king's wife had a dream at night of a nine-colored deer, and wanted to obtain its skin and horns. She then pretended to be sick and did not get up.
The king asked the wife, saying:
'Why do you not get up?'
The wife replied, saying:

'Last night I dreamed of an extraordinary deer with fur of nine different colors and horns white as snow. I think of making a robe from its skin and a whisk handle from its horns. You, O King, should obtain it for me. If you, O King, do not obtain it, I will surely die.'
The king told the wife:
'You should get up first. As I am the king of a country, what cannot be obtained?'
The king then issued a proclamation in the country, saying:ğŸ”½If anyone can obtain the skin and horns of a nine-colored deer, I will reward them with half the country.

'If anyone can catch the nine-colored deer, I will give them half the country to rule, and I will give them a golden bowl filled with silver grains, and I will give them a silver bowl filled with golden grains.'
The drowning man, hearing the king's generous offer, gave rise to an evil thought in his mind:
'If I speak of this deer, I can obtain wealth and nobility. The deer is an animal, what does it matter if it lives or dies?'
He then said to the recruiter:
'I know where the nine-colored deer is.'
The recruiter then took him to the king and said:
'This man knows where the nine-colored deer is.'
The king, hearing this, was greatly delighted and said:
'If you can obtain its skin and antlers, I will give you half the country in return.'
Thereupon, a leprous sore immediately appeared on the drowning man's face.
The drowning man said:
'Although this deer is an animal, it has great spiritual power. The king should bring many soldiers and troops, only then will it be possible to catch it.'
The king then brought out a large number of soldiers and troops and went to the banks of the Ganges River.
The crow, perched in a tree, saw the king's men coming from afar. Suspecting they would kill the deer, it called out to the deer:
Get up!
The king is coming to take you.
The deer still lay there, unaware. The crow said again:
Friend, get up!
The king's troops are coming.
The deer still did not wake up. The crow then flew down from the tree, perched on its head, and pecked its ears:
Friend, get up!
The king's troops surround you in layers.
The deer was startled awake and looked around. There was no way to run, so it went to the side of the king's carriage.
The people nearby drew their bows to shoot it, but the king said:
Do not shoot this deer. This deer is extraordinary. Could it be a divine spirit?
The deer then said:
Do not shoot and kill me. Give me a moment. I have a favor to repay to the country.
The king asked:
What favor?
I once saved the life of a person in the king's country.
He then knelt for a long time and asked the king:
Who said I was here?
The king said:
The leper by the side of the carriage.
The deer raised its head to look at the man, tears streaming from its eyes, unable to contain itself:
Great king!
This man was originally drowning in the water, following the current downstream, sometimes emerging, sometimes submerging, clinging to a tree, looking up and calling out to heaven:
Mountain spirits, tree spirits, various heavenly dragon spirits, why do you not have pity on me?
At that time, I did not spare my life, jumped into the water, and carried the man out. We originally vowed not to tell on each other;
But people are not as good as a floating log in the water.
When the king heard the deer's words, he had a look of shame:
My people have no righteousness.
The king then gave his people three teachings:ğŸ”½Alas!
Alas!
How can one repay kindness by wanting to kill the benefactor?
The king then released the deer to leave:
'In the lower country, if anyone chases after this deer, I will punish you and your five relatives.'
Then, the king returned to the palace.
The deer returned to its old place.

At that time, all the deer in the country came to rely on it. In groups of thousands, they were never harmed. They ate and drank water and grass together, and did not violate people's vegetables and grains;
From then on, the wind and rain were timely, the five grains were abundant, the people were without illness, and at that time, the world was at peace, and they passed away at the end of their lives.
The Buddha said to the disciples:
Although the Bodhisattva practiced, even when he was an animal, he did not abandon compassion, and both humans and beasts were saved.
The one who was the wife at that time is SundarÄ«;
The one who was the crow at that time is Ä€nanda;ğŸ”½The one who was drowning at that time is Devadatta;
The one who was the deer at that time is myself.
Devadatta and I have had enmity for lifetimes;
Ä€nanda has utmost sincerity and attained the Way.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
